CreditLine: Acquired by Henry Walters with the Massarenti Collection, 1902
Description: Like Van Dyck's "Virgin and Child" (Walters 37.234), this idyll of Mary steadying the infant Jesus is centered on the naked child. Representing Christ explicitly as a boy (not sexless) underlined his miraculously dual nature, fully human and fully god. While depicting the adult Christ naked would cause scandal, a naked baby is natural. A drawing by the German master Albrecht Dürer (1471-1528) was the source for the composition, but the style is from around 1600. The drawing was then owned by Emperor Rudolf II in Prague who commissioned copies from court artists. Painting on copper creates an enamel-like surface that satisfied collector's taste for refinement. Further analysis within the "Chamber of Wonders" installation and bibliography

Title: Virgin and Child in a Landscape
